Award.AwardTitle: IDBR: TYPE A - Development of an In situ Single-cell Mass Spectrometer for Mapping Small-molecule Expression in the Developing Embryo
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to the George Washington University to develop a device that will be able to measure the production of broad types of biomolecules in multiple, individual cells of the developing embryo. This project will enhance education by integrating biology and chemistry, and provide new investigative tools to raise creative research opportunities in basic and applied research. Development of the single-cell mass spectrometer will require regular interactions between analytical chemists, biologists, mass spectrometrists, and curators of data repositories, essentially creating an interdisciplinary environment for students and researchers to accomplish training beyond the classical curriculum in these disciplines. By demonstrating the device at the George Washington University and discussing its design, performance, and use at national conferences and publications, this work will broaden scientific literacy and inform of the availability of the device to a broader base of users. Data resulting from measurements on the production of biomolecules during embryogenesis will be disseminated in publicly accessible data repositories, providing a larger number of users with access to facilitate research and education in cell and developmental biology and neuroscience. Notably, the combination of these scientific and outreach elements, including participation of local high-school students in the project, will enhance research and education at the interface of biology, instrument development, and analytical chemistry, providing interdisciplinary solutions to current and future challenges in science and education.

Characterization of biomolecular expression in single cells of the embryo will provide new insights into basic biochemical mechanisms that orchestrate embryonic development, the complex suite of processes by which a fertilized egg gives rise to an entire, fully functioning organism such as the frog, fish, or human. Although it has been technologically feasible to measure genes and transcripts in single embryonic cells, a lack of analytical technology has so far hindered the characterization of proteins, peptides, and metabolites in single embryonic cells. This project will provide one such technological innovation, a single-cell mass spectrometer, by combining traditional tools in cell and developmental biology and neuroscience with next-generation instrumentation from bioanalytical chemistry. Specifically, optical microscopy, microinjection, microcapillary electrophoresis, and nanoelectrospray ionization will be adapted to high-resolution tandem mass spectrometry to determine the production of biomolecules, proteins to metabolites, in multiple cells of the embryo using the frog Xenopus laevis and zebrafish as models. The instrument will be developed in collaboration with leading mass spectrometric industry, biologists, and students, and will be tested by biologists and students working with these important developmental models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

Overview. Characterization of molecules produced by a cell is essential to understand the molecular mechanism of cell differentiation.  However, mass spectrometry, which is the modern technology of choice for proteins, peptides, and metabolites, requires the pooling of thousands-to-millions of cells together to obtain sufficient detection sensitivity, thus losing important information specific to each single cell.  This work developed a new instrument to enable the detection of biomolecules in single cells in live, developing embryos of the South African clawed frog (Xenopus laevis) and zebrafish (Danio rerio), the benchmark vertebrate models in cell and developmental biology.

Intellectual Merit. This work developed an ultrasensitive mass spectrometer platform and related experimental workflow that enabled the detection of proteins, peptides, and metabolites in single cells in live embryos of X. laevis and zebrafish. After identifying the cell of interest under a microscope, a microfabricated capillary was used to aspirate the content of the cell, and the collected material was processed in a microvial for analysis. Molecular detection and quantification were performed using a custom-built capillary electrophoresis electrospray ionization high-resolution mass spectrometer. This work also developed single-cell analysis workflows to allow for assaying the molecular status of identified cells in live embryos. The data resulting from this work uncovered previously unknown molecular (metabolomic and proteomic) differences between embryonic cells (blastomeres) that reproducibly give rise to different types of tissues. The technology was validated to be scalable in space and time, thus raising an exciting new technical capability to study proteins, peptides, and metabolites in single cells during differentiation.

Broader Impacts. This research intertwined two distinct disciplines to simultaneously advance both: instrumental analytical chemistry and cell/developmental biology. The newly developed instrument enabled the molecular assaying of single differentiating cells in live embryos, providing unprecedented molecular information to help better understand cell and developmental processes. Scientific results, protocols, and details of the instrument and the related protocols were disseminated in the form of 5 peer-reviewed publications and ~70 presentations (posters and talks) at (inter)national meetings and interest groups. With direct collaboration between biologists and chemists, this work not only efficiently overcame current technical limitations in biomolecular analysis for cell biology, but it also opened new directions in the study of molecular changes during cell differentiation as well as tissue development and organogenesis. Several new types of basic scientific questions were raised and answered regarding embryonic development in this work.  This project has provided interdisciplinary training to 16 scientists spanning biology and chemistry at all career levels, including 3 senior investigators (1 Professor in Chemistry and 2 Professors in Biology), 1 postdoctoral fellow, 1 technician, and 4 PhD Graduate Students, as well as 3 (under)graduate (M.S./B.S.) and 4 high-school students. By working at the interface of chemistry and biology, these trainees are uniquely positioned to answer current questions in these scientific fields and also to open new types of investigative directions to help better understand basic biological processes relating to the functional building block of life: the cell.
